subject: History
title: The Pill That Changed Society
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Pill That Changed Society.

hook.text: In 1960, a tiny pill gave women control over reproduction for the first time. Society was never the same.

buildup.text: Margaret Sanger and Katherine McCormick funded research. Gregory Pincus developed an oral contraceptive.

discovery.text: The FDA approved Enovid in 1960. Within five years, 6.5 million American women were taking it.

twist.text: Early versions had dangerous side effectsâ€”blood clots and strokes. Safer low-dose versions took years to develop.

climax.text: The Pill fueled the sexual revolution, increased women's workforce participation, and reshaped family structures.

punchline.text: One pill rewrote the rules of society.

quiz.question: What broader social change did the birth control pill help accelerate?
options: The decline of organized religion in America
Increased women's workforce participation and family planning
The end of racial segregation in the United States
